data.title: How many countries are in the Olympics and who isn’t involved?
data.meta_description: A look at how many countries and athletes are participating in the Paris 2024 Olympics and which nations are not competing, which includes Russia.
data.text:
The 2024 Paris Olympics are entering the finish straight with countries battling it out to secure the final gold medals on offer at the Games.

The USA and China, as expected, are fighting to finish top of the medal table after another dominant showing by the two sporting superpowers.

The likes of Australia, France and Great Britain are also enjoying a strong showing in Paris, whist Ireland are celebrating their most successful Olympics ever in terms of medals.

However, a small handful of countries are not participating in the Olympics this year.

Follow Metro.co.uk’s live blog for updates from the Paris 2024 Olympics

How many countries are in the Olympics?

A total of 206 countries are taking part in the Paris 2024 Olympics, with 184 set to be involved in the Paralympics.

Three non-UN-member countries are participating in the Olympics; Taiwan, Palestine and Kosovo, with all three having National Olympic Committees meaning they are eligible to be involved in the Games.

Taiwan, which is claimed by China but governed as an independent state, competes under the name Chinese Taipei under an historic compromise made between the country and China. Taipei is the capital of Taiwan.

South Sudan is the newest Olympic nation, competing in its third Games since gaining independence from Sudan in 2011.

How many athletes are there in the Olympics?

Around 10,500 athletes are competing in the Paris 2024 Olympics.

Which countries aren’t in the Olympics?

Russia and Belarus are currently banned from the Olympics due to the ongoing war with Ukraine.

However, 15 Russian and 17 Belarussian athletes are taking part in Paris as ‘Individual Neutral Athletes’ (AIN).

To compete in the Olympics, the Individual Neutral Athletes must not have publicly supported the war.

The athletes are competing in neutral colours, under a neutral flag and an International Olympic Committee-approved anthem is played when they win a gold medal.

Medals won by AIN competitors are also not included in the final medal table.

Vatican City is the only independent country in the world without an International Olympic Committee, having never applied to join, although it has signaled its intention to do so one day.
